THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court

	
		
			
				The State, Petitioner/Respondent,
				v.
				Danny Orlando
      Wharton, Respondent/Petitioner.
			
		
	


ON WRIT OF CERTIORARI TO THE COURT OF
  APPEALS

Appeal from Greenville County
Â C. Victor Pyle, Jr., Circuit Court Judge
Opinion No.Â  26591
Heard December 3, 2008 - Filed February 2,
  2009 
AFFIRMED IN PART; VACATED IN PART


	
		
			
				Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney 
				General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General 
				Salley W. Elliott, Senior Assistant Attorney General Norman Mark 
				Rapoport, all of Columbia, and Solicitor Robert M. Ariail, of 
				Greenville, for Petitioner/ Respondent.
				Chief
  Appellate Defender Joseph L. Savitz, III, of South Carolina Commission on
  Indigent Defense, Division of Appellate Defense, of Columbia, for
  Respondent/Petitioner.
			
		
	


CHIEF JUSTICE TOAL:Â Â Â Â  Danny Orlando Wharton
  was charged with murder and possession of
  a weapon during a violent crime following the shooting death of Chris Luster
  (Victim).Â  The trial court charged the jury on the law of murder and voluntary
  manslaughter, but refused to charge the jury on involuntary manslaughter and
  accident.Â  The jury found Wharton guilty of voluntary manslaughter and weapons
  possession.Â  The court of appeals held that the trial court erred in giving a
  voluntary manslaughter charge and reversed Whartonâ€™s conviction.Â  State v.
    Wharton, 366 S.C. 56, 620 S.E.2d 83 (Ct. App. 2005).Â  This Court granted a
  writ of certiorari to review the court of appealsâ€™ decision.Â  We affirm in part
  and vacate in part.
Factual/Procedural Background
On the
  evening of the shooting, Wharton and a group of friends were at a house playing cards and drinking.Â  Pamela Suber, Whartonâ€™s ex-girlfriend, arrived at the house and began arguing with
  Wharton over Whartonâ€™s new girlfriend.Â  After Suber left, Wharton became
  extremely angry and resisted his friendsâ€™ attempts to calm him.Â  He then made a
  call to another person, in which he stated that â€œI ainâ€™t going to be punked out
  no moreâ€ and instructed the person to bring a weapon to the house.Â  
At trial, Chraius
  Geter testified that after Wharton made the call, a car arrived at the house.Â  Wharton
  retrieved a gun from inside the car and began walking in the street, swinging
  the gun.Â  Wharton then â€œbumpedâ€ Clifton Shaw, another friend at the house and
  again said â€œI ainâ€™t going to be punked.â€Â  Geter testified that Shaw stated that
  he did not want to fight Wharton, but Wharton â€œswung the gun like was pointing
  to shoot in the airâ€ and the gun fired, fatally hitting Victim.Â  
Edward
  Morris Wharton (Edward) testified that after Suber left, Wharton went into a
  rage and that when Wharton and Shaw began arguing, Victim attempted to prevent
  the two men from fighting.Â  Edward testified that Shaw placed his chain necklace
  down his shirt as if they were about to fight.Â  Wharton then retrieved the
  gun from the car and pulled it out meaning to fire a shot into the air, but
  fatally shot Victim instead.Â  
Shawâ€™s
  testimony was consistent with both Edwardâ€™s and Geterâ€™s testimonies.Â  However,
  Shaw added that when Wharton retrieved the gun from the car, the gun was
  wrapped in a shirt and that Wharton pulled it out from the shirt into the air
  when it discharged.Â  
The
  trial court charged the jury on possession of a weapon during the commission of
  a violent crime, murder, and, over Whartonâ€™s objection, voluntary
  manslaughter.Â  He denied Whartonâ€™s request for an involuntary manslaughter and
  accident charge.Â  The jury found Wharton guilty of voluntary manslaughter and
  weapons possession.Â  The court of appeals reversed and held that the trial
  court erred in charging voluntary manslaughter because there was no evidence of
  sufficient legal provocation on behalf of Victim and that transferred intent
  does not apply to voluntary manslaughter.Â  The court went on to hold that even
  if transferred intent applied, there was no evidence of sufficient legal
  provocation on the part of Shaw.Â  
This
  Court granted the Stateâ€™s petition for a writ of certiorari, and the State
  presents the following issues for review:

	
		
			I.
			Did the court of appeals err
  holding there was no evidence of sufficient legal provocation?
 
		
		
			II.
			Did the court of appeals err in
  holding the doctrine of transferred intent does not apply to voluntary
  manslaughter?
		
	

Wharton
  also filed a petition for a writ of certiorari.Â  We granted Whartonâ€™s petition,
  and Wharton presents the following issues for review:Â  

	
		
			I.
			Did the trial court err in refusing to charge the 
			jury on involuntary manslaughter?
 
		
		
			II.
			Did the court of appeals err in holding the 
			doctrine of transferred intent does not apply to voluntary 
			manslaughter?
		
	

Standard of Review
In criminal cases, the appellate court sits to review errors of
  law only. Â State v. Baccus, 367 S.C. 41, 48, 625 S.E.2d 216, 220 (2006).Â 
  A trial courtâ€™s decision regarding jury charges will not be reversed where the charges,
  as a whole, properly charged the law to be applied. Â State v. Rye, 375
  S.C. 119, 123, 651 S.E.2d 321, 323 (2007).
Law/Analysis
Stateâ€™s Issues
I. Sufficient
  Legal Provocation
The State argues that the court of appeals erred in
  holding that there was no evidence of sufficient legal provocation warranting a
  voluntary manslaughter charge.Â  We disagree.
Voluntary manslaughter is the unlawful killing of a human
  being in sudden heat of passion upon sufficient legal provocation.Â  State v. Pittman, 373
  S.C. 527, 572, 647 S.E.2d 144, 167 (2007).Â 
  The sudden heat of passion, upon sufficient legal provocation, while it need
  not dethrone reason entirely, or shut out knowledge and volition, must be such
  as would naturally disturb the sway of reason, and render the mind of an
  ordinary person incapable of cool reflection, and produce what, according to
  human experience, may be called an uncontrollable impulse to do violence.Â  Id.Â  To warrant the court in eliminating the offense of manslaughter it should very
  clearly appear that there is no evidence whatsoever tending to reduce the crime
  from murder to manslaughter.Â  Id. at 572, 647 S.E.2d at 168.
In our
  view, there is no evidence in
  the record of sufficient legal provocation.Â  Testimony showed that Wharton was
  in a rage after his argument with Suber and that several people were trying to
  calm him.Â  After attempts to calm him failed, Wharton deliberately instructed
  someone to bring him a gun, despite there being no threat of another person
  with a weapon.Â  There was no evidence showing Victim provoked Wharton, and
  although there was evidence that Wharton and Shaw argued and exchanged words,
  there was no evidence Shaw posed a threat to Wharton either by possessing a
  weapon or through hostile acts.Â  See State v. Byrd, 323
  S.C. 319, 322, 474 S.E.2d 430, 432 (1996)
  (holding that where death is caused by the use of a deadly
  weapon, words alone, however opprobrious, are not sufficient to constitute a
  legal provocation, but words accompanied by hostile acts may, according to the
  circumstances, reduce a charge from murder to voluntary manslaughter).Â  
While Wharton may have been in a rage and acting under a sudden
  heat of passion, there is no evidence of sufficient legal provocation.Â  See
    Pittman, 373 S.C. at 573, 647 S.E.2d at 168 (recognizing that both heat of
  passion and sufficient legal provocation must be present at the time of the
  killing).Â  Accordingly, we hold that the trial court erred in charging the jury
  on voluntary manslaughter.
II. Transferred Intent
The State
  argues that the court of appeals erred in holding that the doctrine of
  transferred intent was inapplicable to voluntary manslaughter.Â  We decline to
  address this issue.Â  
In State
  v. Childers, 373 S.C. 367, 645 S.E.2d 233
  (2007), the plurality of this Court held that the doctrine of transferred
  intent was not applicable to voluntary manslaughter cases because the overt act
  that produces the sudden heat of passion must come from the victim.Â  However,
  the dissent would have held that if a defendant kills an unintentional victim
  upon sufficient legal provocation committed by a third party, the doctrine of
  transferred intent applies, entitling the defendant to a voluntary manslaughter
  charge.Â  
In this case, the court of appeals held that the trial court erred
  in charging the jury on voluntary manslaughter because there was no evidence of
  sufficient legal provocation and because transferred intent does not apply to
  voluntary manslaughter.Â  We find, however, that Childers was not a
  majority opinion, and the applicability of the doctrine of transferred intent to
  voluntary manslaughter cases where the defendant kills an unintended
  victim upon sufficient legal provocation committed by a third party remains an
  unsettled question in South Carolina.Â  However, because we find no evidence of
  sufficient legal provocation by a third party in this case, we need not address
  this issue.Â  We therefore vacate the portion of the court of appealsâ€™ opinion
  addressing this issue.Â  
Whartonâ€™s Issues
I. Involuntary Manslaughter
Petitioner argues
  the trial judge erred in refusing to charge the jury on involuntary
  manslaughter.Â  We disagree.
Involuntary manslaughter is (1) the unintentional killing of another without malice, but while
  engaged in an unlawful activity not naturally tending to cause death or great
  bodily harm; or (2) the unintentional killing of another without malice, while
  engaged in a lawful activity with reckless disregard for the safety of others.Â  State v. Chatman, 336 S.C. 149, 152, 519 S.E.2d 100, 101 (1999).Â  If there is any evidence warranting a
  charge on involuntary manslaughter, then the charge must be given.Â  State v. Reese, 370
  S.C. 31, 36, 633 S.E.2d 898, 900 (2006).
In our
  view, there is no evidence supporting an involuntary manslaughter charge.Â  Even
  assuming Wharton did not intentionally fire the gun at Shaw, by pointing the
  gun and waiving it in the air, Wharton committed an unlawful act that would naturally
  tend to cause death or great bodily harm.Â  Accordingly, we hold the trial court
  properly denied his request for an involuntary manslaughter charge.
II. Accident
Wharton argues the trial court erred in
  refusing to charge the jury on the law of accident.Â  We disagree.
For a homicide to be excusable on the ground of accident, it must
  be shown that the killing was unintentional, the defendant was acting lawfully,
  and due care was exercised in the handling of the weapon.Â  State v. Burriss, 334
  S.C. 256, 259, 513 S.E.2d 104, 106 (1999). Â Evidence
  of an accidental discharge of a gun will support a charge of accident where the
  defendant lawfully arms himself in self-defense.Â  Tisdale v.
    State, 378 S.C. 122, 126, 662 S.E.2d
  410, 412 (2008).
There
  is no evidence in the record to support an accident charge.Â  Specifically,
  Wharton was not acting lawfully in waiving the gun in the air, nor did he
  exercise due care in handling the weapon.Â  Furthermore, there is no evidence he
  was lawfully armed in self-defense.Â  Accordingly, we hold that the trial court
  properly denied Whartonâ€™s request for a charge on the law of accident.Â  
Conclusion
For the foregoing reasons, we hold that the trial court properly
  denied Whartonâ€™s request to charge the jury on involuntary manslaughter and
  accident, but that the trial court erred in charging the jury on voluntary
  manslaughter.Â  Furthermore, we vacate the portion of the court of appeals
  opinion regarding the doctrine of transferred intent in regard to voluntary
  manslaughter.Â  Accordingly, we affirm in part and vacate in part the court of
  appealsâ€™ decision.Â  
WALLER, PLEICONES,
  JJ., and Acting Justices James E. Moore and Dorothy Mobley Jones, concur.

  The
  Supreme Court of South Carolina

  
    
      
        James S.
          Richardson and Karolina M. Richardson, Petitioners,
        v.
        Donald Hawkins
          Construction, Inc., Donald Hawkins, Sharon Preu, as Personal Representative
          for the Estate of Joseph Taylor and James Hodge, Defendants,
        Of Whom Donald
          Hawkins Construction, Inc. and Donald Hawkins are Respondents.
      
    
  


ORDER

Respondents have filed a
  petition for rehearing.Â Â  The petition for rehearing is denied.Â  The original
  opinion, however, is hereby withdrawn and the attached opinion is substituted
in its place.

  
    
     s/Jean H. Toal                                    C.J.
              
              s/John H. Waller, Jr.                           J.
              
              s/Costa M. Pleicones                        J.
            s/Donald W. Beatty                            J.
      s/Larry B. Hyman, Jr.                         A.J.
    
  

Columbia, South Carolina
February 9, 2009

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court


  
    
      
        James S.
          Richardson and Karolina M. Richardson, Petitioners,
        v.
        Donald Hawkins
          Construction, Inc., Donald Hawkins, Sharon Preu, as Personal Representative
          for the Estate of Joseph Taylor and James Hodge, Defendants,
        Of Whom Donald
          Hawkins Construction, Inc. and Donald Hawkins are Respondents.
      
    
  


ON WRIT OF CERTIORARI TO THE COURT OF APPEALS

Appeal From Clarendon County
Â Howard P. King, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No.Â  26575
  Heard October 22, 2008 - Re-filed February
9, 2009Â  

REVERSED


  
    
      
        Steven
          Smith McKenzie, of Manning, for Petitioners.
        Kenneth
          R. Young, Jr., of Sumter, for Respondents.
      
    
  


JUSTICE
  WALLER:Â   We granted petitionersâ€™
  request for a writ of certiorari to review the Court of Appealsâ€™ opinion in Richardson
    v. Donald Hawkins Constr., Inc., 370 S.C. 125, 634 S.E.2d 9 (Ct. App.
2006).Â  We reverse.
FACTS
Petitioners
  James and Karolina Richardson purchased a house from respondents Donald Hawkins Construction and Donald
  Hawkins in 1999. After moving in, petitioners
  noticed several cosmetic and structural problems with the house. Â Initially,
  respondents sent a representative to repair the problems, but as the problems
  persisted, respondents stopped responding to petitionersâ€™ service requests. Â In
  February 2001, petitioners retained legal counsel who contacted respondents by
  letter about completing the home repairs.Â  Counselâ€™s letter demanded a response
  by March 7, 2001; respondents never answered the letter.
On March 12, 2001, petitionersâ€™
  residence was severely damaged by a fire that investigators concluded was
  intentionally set.
On
  May 21, 2002, the police questioned Joseph Taylor about the arson.Â  Taylor, an
  employee of respondent Hawkins, gave the police a written statement in which he
  claimed to have overheard Hawkins ask another coworker, James Hodge, to burn
  down petitionersâ€™ house because petitioners were threatening to sue him due to
  the problems with the house (â€œStatement Oneâ€). Â Â According to Statement One, Hodge
  later told him Hawkins offered him $2,000 to burn the house down; a few days
  later, Taylor learned that Hodge had set the fire but had not succeeded in
  burning the entire house down.

Due
  to investigatorsâ€™ suspicions that Taylor was more involved in the arson than he
  revealed in Statement One, he was interviewed again later that afternoon. Â Following
  this interview, Taylor submitted another written statement to the police (â€œStatement
  Twoâ€). Â In Statement Two, Taylor admitted that Hawkins approached both him and Hodge and offered them $2,000 to burn down petitionersâ€™ house. Â While Taylor acted as lookout, Hodge crawled under the house and ignited a jug filled with
  flammable liquid. Â The following day, Hodge told Taylor that, because the house
  was not completely destroyed, Hawkins gave him only $1,000. Â Taylor claimed he did
  not get any money for his role as lookout.Â  
Two
  days after giving the police the written statements, Taylor wrote and signed
  the following statement (â€œStatement Threeâ€) before two witnesses and a notary:

  I Joseph
    Taylor has [sic] never been paid by Donnie Hawkins for doing anything illeagle
    [sic]. Â Donnie paided [sic] me for subcontracting carpentry work only. Â I have
    never heard or seen him pay anyone to do anything illeagle [sic]! Â 

According
  to Taylorâ€™s mother, Sharon Preu, Taylor visited her shortly after being
  questioned by the police and told her that the statements he had made to police
  were â€œall a lie.â€ Â During trial, Preuâ€™s testimony was proffered.Â  Preu stated
  that Taylor told her the police â€œhad him in Sumter all day long and ... cussed
  at him.â€ Â According to Preu, Taylor said he was promised no jail time if he confessed,
  so he told police that he â€œand Mr. Hodge had done it and that it was all a lie,
  that they had offered him two years probation if he was to go along with it.â€Â (â€œStatement Fourâ€).
Petitioners consented to having
  all criminal charges regarding the arson dropped in order to pursue a civil
  case. Â Thereafter, a civil suit was filed against Taylor, Hodge, Hawkins, and
  Donald Hawkins Construction, Inc. Â Taylor was served a summons and complaint, but he failed to
  file an answer. Â In May 2003, petitioners filed an affidavit
  of default as to defendant Taylor. Â In January 2004, before the case went to
  trial, Taylor died in an unrelated automobile accident.
In
  September 2004, the trial court ruled on several pre-trial matters, including
  the admissibility of Statements One, Two, and Three. Â First, the trial court
  ruled on the status of petitionersâ€™ case against Taylorâ€™s estate, represented
  after his death by Preu. Â The trial court found that Taylorâ€™s default prior to
  his death put the estate in the procedural posture of having admitted all of
  the allegations contained in the complaint. Â As to Statements One and Two, the
  court found them admissible against the remaining defendants under the
  statements against interest exception to hearsay described in Rule 804(b)(3),
  SCRE.[1] Â As to Statement Three, however, the circuit court excluded
  Taylorâ€™s own written statement under Rule 403, SCRE.Â  The circuit court
  concluded that the probative value of the written statement was substantially
  outweighed by the danger of unfair prejudice because, due to his default, Taylor was deemed to have admitted all allegations in the complaint.[2]
At trial,
  the defense proffered the testimony of Preu concerning Taylorâ€™s statements to
  her after he had been questioned by police (i.e., Statement Four). Â Petitioners
  objected on hearsay grounds, and the trial court found the statement did not
  fall within a hearsay exception.Â  The trial court further stated that Taylorâ€™s statements to Preu simply were denials of his involvement in the arson and thus, ruled
  them inadmissible.
At
  the conclusion of trial, the jury found the defendants liable and awarded petitioners
  $84,758 in actual damages and $150,000 in punitive damages against Hawkins
  Construction; $5,500 in actual damages and $5,000 in punitive damages against
  Hodge; and $5,500 in actual damages and $250,000 in punitive damages against
  Hawkins.[3] Â The jury did not award petitioners any damages
  against Taylorâ€™s estate. 
Only
  Respondents Donald Hawkins Construction, Inc. and Hawkins appealed from the juryâ€™s
  verdict.Â  The Court of Appeals reversed and remanded for a new trial.
The
  Court of Appeals based its reversal on Rule 806, SCRE.[4]Â  Because Taylorâ€™s first two statements were admitted under hearsay rules
  801 and 804, the Court of Appeals concluded that â€œ[p]ursuant to Rule 806 and
  basic concepts of fairness,â€ the defense should have been allowed to impeach Taylor with evidence that was inconsistent with Statements One and Two.Â  Richardson,
  370 S.C. at 130, 634 S.E.2d at 12.
ISSUE

  Did the
    Court of Appeals err in reversing the trial courtâ€™s decision to exclude
    Taylorâ€™s Statements Three and Four?


DISCUSSION
Petitioners
  argue the trial court did not abuse its discretion by finding Statements Three
  and Four inadmissible, and therefore the Court of Appeals erred by reversing
  the trial courtâ€™s decision to exclude the evidence.Â  We agree.
Evidence
  is relevant and admissible if it has any tendency to make the existence of any
  fact that is of consequence to the determination of the action more probable or
  less probable than it would be without the evidence. Â Rules 401, 402, SCRE.Â  Relevant
  evidence may be excluded, however, â€œif its probative value is substantially
  outweighed by the danger of unfair prejudice, confusion of the issues, or
  misleading the jury.â€Â Rule 403,
  SCRE. 
It
  is well settled that the admission and rejection of testimony is largely within
  the trial courtâ€™s sound discretion,
  the exercise of which will not be disturbed on appeal absent an abuse of that discretion. Â E.g., Pike v. South Carolina Depâ€™t of
    Transp., 343 S.C. 224, 234, 540 S.E.2d 87, 92 (2000)
In
  our opinion, it was within the trial courtâ€™s discretion to exclude Taylorâ€™s Statements Three and Four pursuant to Rule 403, SCRE.Â  In its pretrial Rule 403
  ruling, the trial court noted the unusual procedural posture of the case because
  of defendant Taylorâ€™s default.Â  The trial court found that because Taylor was considered to have admitted the allegations of the complaint, his statements denying
  the same allegations would be unduly prejudicial.Â  Likewise, the trial court
  excluded Statement Four in part because it amounted to a denial of the
  allegations that were already deemed admitted by Taylor.Â  The trial court
  clearly believed that by admitting these statements, the jury would have been
  misled and/or confused on the issues presented, and therefore, the court properly
  excluded them.Â  See Rule 403, SCRE; see also Rule 220, SCACR
  (this Court may affirm any ruling based upon any ground appearing in the
  record).Â  Given the factual and procedural circumstances of the instant case,
  we hold the trial court did not err in this determination.

CONCLUSION
We find the trial court did not abuse its discretion
  in excluding Taylorâ€™s Statements Three and Four.Â  Accordingly, we reverse the
  Court of Appealsâ€™ decision, and reinstate the juryâ€™s verdict, as modified by
  post-trial order.[5]
REVERSED.
TOAL,
  C.J., PLEICONES, KITTREDGE, JJ., and Acting Justice Larry B. Hyman, Jr.,
  concur.


[1] At trial, the circuit revised its basis for the
  admission of Statement One. The circuit court found Statement One admissible as
  a statement by a co-conspirator of a party during the course and furtherance of
  a conspiracy pursuant to Rule 801(d)(2)(E), SCRE.Â  The circuit court upheld its
  ruling in limine on Statement Two, admitting the statement under the
  statement against interest exception to hearsay.
[2] For example, the Complaint specifically alleged that
  Hawkins agreed to pay Hodge and Taylor $2,000 to burn down petitionersâ€™ house.
[3] By post-trial order, the punitive damages award
  against Hawkins was reduced from $250,000 to $49,500.
[4] Rule 806 provides:

  When a
    hearsay statement, or a statement defined in Rule 801(d)(2)(C), (D), or (E) has
    been admitted in evidence, the credibility of the declarant may be attacked,
    and if attacked may be supported, by any evidence which would be admissible for
    those purposes if declarant had testified as a witness.Â  Evidence of a
    statement or conduct by the declarant at any time, inconsistent with the
    declarantâ€™s hearsay statement, is not subject to any requirement that the
    declarant may have been afforded an opportunity to deny or explain.

[5] See footnote 3, supra.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court

	
		
			
				Larry Tucker
      Gay, Jr., Appellant,
				v.
				Robert M.
      Ariail, in his official capacity as Solicitor, Thirteenth Judicial Circuit,
      and the South Carolina Law Enforcement Division, Respondents.
			
		
	


Appeal from Greenville County
Â Larry R. Patterson, Circuit Court Judge
Opinion No. 26592
Heard December 2, 2008 - Filed February 9,
  2009Â Â  
REVERSED


	
		
			
				Jon
  Rene Josey, of Turner, Padget, Graham & Laney, of Florence, for Appellant.
				Attorney
  General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh
  and Assistant Attorney General David Spencer, of Columbia, for Respondent.
			
		
	


JUSTICE
  WALLER:Â  Appellant, Larry Tucker Gay appeals
  an order of the circuit court finding him ineligible to apply for expungement
  of his criminal record.Â  We reverse.
FACTS
In 1990, when he was twenty-two years old, Gay pled
  guilty to assault and battery of a high and aggravated nature (ABHAN).Â  He
  received a ten-year sentence, suspended on five years probation.Â  Sixteen years
  later, in June 2006, Gay sought to have the record of that conviction
  expunged.Â  The circuit court held that because Gay was sentenced as an adult,
  he was ineligible for expungement under S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 22-5-920(2007).Â  
ISSUE
Did the court err
  in ruling Gay was ineligible for expungement?
DISCUSSION
S.C. Code Ann. Â§
  22-5-920(B) permits a defendant who was convicted as a youthful offender to
  apply for an expungement, stating, in part: 

	Following a first offense conviction as a youthful offender, the defendant after
  fifteen years from the date of the conviction may apply, or cause someone
  acting on his behalf to apply, to the circuit court for an order expunging the
  records of the arrest and conviction. However, this section does not apply to
  an offense involving. . .Â  to an offense classified as a violent crime in
  Section 16-1-60,[1].
  . . . If the defendant has had no other conviction during the fifteen year
  period following the first offense conviction as a youthful offender, the
  circuit court may issue an order expunging the records. . . .

(Emphasis supplied).Â  S.C.
  Code Ann. Â§ 24-19-10 defines â€œyouthful offenderâ€ as follows:


	d)
  â€œYouthful offenderâ€ means an offender who is: 
	(ii) seventeen
  but less than twenty five years of age at the time of conviction for an offense
  that is not a violent crime, as defined in Section 16-1-60, and that is a
  misdemeanor. . . . 
	(f)
  â€œConvictionâ€ means a judgment in a verdict or finding of guilty, plea of guilty,
  or plea of nolo contendere to a criminal charge where the imprisonment
  is at least one year, but excluding all offenses in which the maximum
  punishment provided by law is death or life imprisonment.Â  (Emphasis
  supplied).Â  

Gay contends he was a â€œyouthful
  offenderâ€ at the time of his plea in 1990, such that SLED and the circuit court
  erred in ruling he was ineligible to be considered for expungement.Â  The state
  contends that because Gay was sentenced as an adult, he is ineligible for
  expungement under S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 22-5-920(B).Â  We disagree.Â Â  Under the clear
  and unambiguous terms of the statute, Gay was convicted as a â€œyouthful
  offenderâ€ and was therefore entitled to have his application for expungement
  considered.[2] 
In interpreting
  statutes, the Court looks to the plain meaning of the statute and the intent of
  the Legislature.Â  State v. Dingle, 376 S.C. 643, 659 S.E.2d 101(2008).Â 
  All rules of statutory construction are subservient to the maxim that
  legislative intent must prevail if it can be reasonably discovered in the
  language used.Â  State v. Pittman, 373 S.C. 527, 647 S.E.2d 144 (2007), cert.
    denied 128 S.Ct. 1872 (2008).Â  A statuteâ€™s language must be construed in
  light of the intended purpose of the statute.Â  If possible, legislative intent
  should be found in the plain language of the statute itself.Â  If a statuteâ€™s
  language is plain and unambiguous, and conveys a clear and definite meaning,
  the rules of statutory interpretation are not needed and the Court has no right
  to impose another meaning.Â  State v. Gaines, 380 S.C. 23, 667 S.E.2d 728
  (2008).
Here, the statutes
  permit a â€œyouthful offender,â€ i.e., one who is seventeen but less than twenty
  five years of age at the time of conviction, who has â€œpled guiltyâ€ to an
  offense which is not a violent crime, and which was both a first offense and a
  misdemeanor, to apply for an order expunging the records of the arrest and
  conviction.Â Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 24-19-10 and Â§ 22-5-920(B).Â  Gay meets these requirements.Â  
S.C. Code Ann. Â§
  24-19-50 is entitled â€œPowers of courts upon conviction of youthful
  offenders.â€Â Â  It provides as follows:

	In the
  event of a conviction of a youthful offender the court may: 
	(1) suspend
  the sentence and place the youthful offender on probation; 
	(2)
  release the youthful offender to the custody of the division before sentencing
  for an observation and evaluation period of not more than sixty days.Â  The
  observation and evaluation must be conducted by the Reception and Evaluation
  Center operating under joint agreement between the Department of Vocational
  Rehabilitation and the Department of Corrections and the findings and
  recommendations for sentencing must be returned with the youthful offender to
  the court for sentencing; 
	(3) if
  the offender is under the age of twenty one, without his consent, sentence the
  youthful offender indefinitely to the custody of the department for treatment
  and supervision pursuant to this chapter until discharged by the division, the
  period of custody not to exceed six years.Â  If the offender is twenty one years
  of age but less than twenty five years of age, he may be sentenced in
  accordance with this item if he consents in writing; 
	(4) if
  the court finds that the youthful offender will not derive benefit from
  treatment, may sentence the youthful offender under any other applicable
  penalty provision.Â  The youthful offender must be placed in the custody of the
  department; 
	(5) not
  sentence a youthful offender more than once under this chapter.

(emphasis supplied).Â  The
  clear import of the above statute is that a person who meets the definition of
  â€œyouthful offenderâ€ is â€œconvictedâ€ regardless of the manner of sentencing, and
  is eligible to apply for expungement if the requirements of Â§ 22-5-920(b) are
  met.
The state contends
  Gay is ineligible for expungement because he was not sentenced as a
  youthful offender but as an adult.Â  Contrary to the stateâ€™s contention, S.C.
  Code Ann. Â§ 22-5-920(B) requires only that one be convicted as a
  youthful offender.Â  Under the literal terms of the statute, Gay was convicted as a â€œyouthful offender.â€Â  
In Creel v.
  State, 262 S.C. 558, 564, 206 S.E.2d 825, 828 (1974), we held â€œa person
  between the ages of seventeen and twenty-five is, by definition, a youthful
  offender and must be sentenced pursuant to that Act.Â  The trial judge must
  sentence the youthful offender under one of the subsections of Section 55-395
  (the predecessor to S.C. Code Ann. 24-19-50).â€Â  Although a trial judge has
  discretion to impose sanctions which are â€œoutsideâ€ the YOA, see Â§
  24-19-50(4), the sentencing nonetheless takes place pursuant to the provisions
  of Â§ 24-19-50 of the YOA.Â  
The state relies on Brown v. State, 265 S.C. 516, 220 S.E.2d 125 (1975), cert. denied 426 U.S. 939 (1976), in which the Court found it implicit the trial judge had
  found the defendant would receive no benefit from a YOA sentence.Â  Brown is immaterial to the issue of whether or not an individual who meets the
  statutory definition of â€œyouthful offenderâ€ is eligible for expungement under Â§
  22-5-920(B).Â  
We find the
  Legislature, in enacting Â§ 22-5-920(B), reasonably concluded that persons who
  had been convicted of non-violent, misdemeanor offenses at a young age (between
  17-25), and who had committed no subsequent offenses over the course of the
  next fifteen years, were entitled to be considered for an expungement.Â  Â 
CONCLUSION
The trial court
  erred in ruling Gay was ineligible to have his application for expungement
  considered.Â  Accordingly, the circuit courtâ€™s order is reversed.
REVERSED.
TOAL,
  C.J., PLEICONES, BEATTY and KITTREDGE, JJ., concur.




[1] Â ABHAN is not listed as a violent crime in Â§
  16-1-60.Â  See State v. Rogers, 338 S.C. 435, 527 S.E.2 101
  (2000).Â  ABHAN is a common law misdemeanor punishable by up to ten years in
  prison.Â  State v. Morris, 371 S.C. 278, 639 S.E.2d 53 (2006).Â  
[2] Â The mere fact that Gay is entitled to have his
  application considered does not mean expungement necessarily follows; Gay
  concedes expungement is a privilege and not a right.

title: Dykeman v. Wells Fargo
description: This case involves the interpretation of penal statutes imposing a duty on the record holder of a mortgage on real estate to enter a satisfaction of the mortgage in the proper office, upon the occurrence of certain conditions.  The sole condition before us relates to the requirement in sections 29-3-310 and 320 of the South Carolina Code (2007), that the mortgagor request the mortgagee enter the satisfaction.  In this case, we hold the mortgagor did not make such a request.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court

	
		
			
				William F.
      Dykeman and Leslie L. Dykeman, on behalf of themselves and all others
      similarly situated, Appellants,
				v.
				Wells Fargo
      Home Mortgage, Inc., Respondent.
			
		
	


Appeal From Beaufort County
John C. Few, Circuit Court Judge
Opinion No. 26593
Heard October 22, 2008 - Filed February 9,
  2009
AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				J. Olin
  McDougall, II, of Newman & McDougall, of Beaufort, Timothy E. Eble, of Mt.
  Pleasant, and Tom Young, Jr., Charles W. Whetstone, Jr., Cheryl F. Perkins, all
  of Whetstone, Myers, Perkins & Young, of Columbia, for Appellants.
				Walter
  Keith Martens and Herbert W. Hamilton, both of Hamilton, Martens, Ballou &
  Sipe, of Rock Hill, for Respondent.
				John T.
  Moore, C. Mitchell Brown, and B. Rush Smith, III, all of Nelson, Mullins,
  Riley & Scarborough, of Columbia, for Amicus Curiae South Carolina Bankers
  Association, and Robert R. Thuss and Susan B. Berkowitz, also of Columbia, for
  Amicus Curiae SC Appleseed Legal Justice Center.
			
		
	


JUSTICE KITTREDGE:Â Â Â Â Â  This case involves the
  interpretation of penal statutes imposing a duty on the record holder of a mortgage
  on real estate to enter a satisfaction of the mortgage in the proper office,
  upon the occurrence of certain conditions.Â  The sole condition before us
  relates to the requirement in sections 29-3-310 and 320 of the South Carolina
  Code (2007), that the mortgagor make a request to the mortgagee to enter the
  satisfaction. Â In this case, we must answer whether the mortgagorâ€™s compliance
  with the â€œborrowerâ€™s responsibilitiesâ€ set by the mortgagee constituted an
  affirmative request from the mortgagor.Â  The circuit court answered in the
  negative and granted the mortgagee summary judgment.Â  We affirm.
I.
In
  June of 2000, William and Leslie Dykeman purchased property in Beaufort County, South Carolina by executing a purchase-money mortgage in favor of Wells
  Fargo.Â  In February of 2002, the Dykemans refinanced the loan with Wells Fargo.Â 
  Wells Fargo provided to the Dykemansâ€™ closing attorney certain documents which
  set forth the â€œborrowerâ€™s responsibilities.â€ Â These documents included a
  transmittal form, a payment coupon, and a complete payoff amount.Â  Part of the
  payoff amount (five dollars) was a payment for â€œrecording fees.â€
The
  Dykemans complied with the â€œborrowerâ€™s responsibilitiesâ€ by completing the
  forms and paying the amount submitted by Wells Fargo, including the five dollar
  recording fee.Â  A check (for the payoff) was mailed to Wells Fargo on or about
  February 28, 2002.Â  The record does not contain a cover letter from the
  Dykemansâ€™ counsel to Wells Fargo, as typically occurs as part of the real
  estate closing process.[1]Â 
  In any event, Wells Fargo acknowledged receipt of the payment and documentation
  pursuant to the â€œborrowerâ€™s responsibilities.â€
Wells
  Fargo did not record the mortgage satisfaction until July 16, 2002, by filing a
  lost mortgage satisfaction with the Beaufort County Register of Deeds.Â  The
  record discloses that the Dykemansâ€™ closing attorney wrote Wells Fargo about a
  month earlier on June 27, 2002, specifically citing to sections 29-3-310 and
  320 and noting that Wells Fargo â€œmay already be liable for the statutory
  penalty.â€ Â Because the mortgage satisfaction was not entered within three
  months after Wells Fargoâ€™s receipt of the mortgage payment and payoff fee, the
  Dykemans brought this statutory claim against Wells Fargo.[2]Â 
  Pursuant to cross-motions for summary judgment, the trial court granted
  judgment for Wells Fargo.Â  The Dykemans appealed, which is before us pursuant
  to Rule 204 (b), SCACR, certification.
II.
We set forth the
  relevant statutory sections requiring the recording of a satisfaction.Â  Section
  29-3-310 provides:

	Any
  holder of record of a mortgage who
    has received full payment or satisfaction or to whom a legal tender has
  been made of his debts, damages, costs, and charges secured by mortgage of real
  estate shall, at the request by certified mail or other form of delivery
    with a proof of delivery of the mortgagor or of his legal representative or
  any other person being a creditor of the debtor or a purchaser under him or
  having an interest in any estate bound by the mortgage and on tender of the
  fees of office for entering satisfaction, within three months after the certified mail, or other form of delivery, with a proof of delivery, 
	request
    is made, enter satisfaction in the proper office on the mortgage which
  shall forever thereafter discharge and satisfy the mortgage.

(emphasis
  added).

	Section
  29-3-320 provides:
	Any
  holder of record of a mortgage having received such payment, satisfaction, or
  tender as aforesaid who shall
    not, by himself or his attorney, within three months after such certified mail, or other form of delivery, with a proof of delivery, 
	request and tender of fees of office, repair to the proper office and enter
      satisfaction as aforesaid shall forfeit and pay to the person aggrieved
        a sum of money not exceeding one-half of the amount of the debt secured by the
        mortgage, or twenty-five thousand dollars, whichever is less, plus actual
        damages, costs, and attorneyâ€™s fees in the discretion of the court, to be
  recovered by action in any court of competent jurisdiction within the State.

(emphasis
  added).
Sections 29-3-310
  and 320 are penal statutes.Â  Penal statutes must be strictly construed.Â  Bostic
    v. Am. Home Mortg. Servicing, Inc., 375 S.C. 143, 149, 650 S.E.2d 479, 482
  (Ct. App. 2007) (â€œSouth Carolina has long recognized the principle that penal
  statutes are to be strictly construed.â€).Â  The Court of Appeals in Rorrer v.
    P.J. Club, Inc., 347 S.C. 560, 567, 556 S.E.2d 726, 730 (Ct. App. 2001)
  expounded:

	The rule
  that penal statutes, as contradistinguished from remedial statutes, must be
  construed strictly, is but a means of arriving at the intention. Â When a law
  imposes a punishment which acts upon the offender alone, and not as a
  reparation to the party injured, and when it is entirely within the discretion
  of the lawgiver, it will not be presumed that he intended it should be extended
  further than is expressed; and humanity would require that it should be so
  limited in the construction as to be certain not to exceed the intention.

Further, the statute as a
  whole must be examined to determine and fulfill the Legislatureâ€™s intent.Â  Sloan
    v. S.C. Bd. of Physical Therapy Examâ€™rs, 370 S.C. 452, 468, 636 S.E.2d 598,
  606-07 (2006) (â€œA statute as a whole must receive practical, reasonable, and
  fair interpretation consonant with the purpose, design, and policy of
  lawmakers.â€).
In Bostic,
  the Court of Appeals interpreted sections 29-3-310 and 320 to determine what
  constitutes a â€œrequest,â€ sufficient to render the mortgagee statutorily liable.
  Â 375 S.C. at 154, 650 S.E.2d at 485. Â The facts in Bostic are similar to
  those before us.Â  Bostic â€œobtained a statement [from the mortgagee] for the
  payoff amount on the loan, which . . . included a â€˜release feeâ€™ and a
  â€˜recording fee.â€™â€ Â Id. at 145, 650 S.E.2d at 480.Â  Bostic sent the funds
  to the mortgagee which acknowledged receipt, but the mortgage was not satisfied
  of record within the statutory three-month period.Â  Id.Â  Bostic, through
  counsel, then sent a certified letter to the mortgagee to two separate
  addresses.Â  Id.Â  The certified letter referenced the statute and
  demanded the statutory penalty.Â  Id. at 145-46, 650 S.E.2d at 480.
Bostic
  filed suit against the mortgagee seeking the statutory penalty and related
  relief.Â  Id. at 146, 650 S.E.2d at 480.Â  The trial court granted Bostic
  summary judgment, but the Court of Appeals reversed.Â  Id. at 144-45, 650
  S.E.2d at 480.Â  The Court of Appeals determined that under the applicable
  statutory scheme, as a matter of law, Bostic failed to make an affirmative
  request to have his mortgage recorded as satisfied.Â  Id. at 156, 650
  S.E.2d at 486.Â  The Bostic court interpreted the element of a request as
  a condition precedent to statutory relief.Â  Id. at 150, 650 S.E.2d at
  483.Â  In this regard, sending the payoff check to the mortgagee did not
  constitute a â€œrequestâ€ within the meaning of the statute.Â  Id. at 155,
  650 S.E.2d at 485.
We agree
  with the Bostic courtâ€™s determination that our Legislature intended a request,
  under the penal statutory framework, â€œoperate to inform the mortgagee of the
  mortgagorâ€™s desire for the satisfied mortgage to be recorded.â€Â  Id. at 154, 650 S.E.2d at 485. Â For liability to attach under the applicable
  statutes, payment of the mortgage is â€œonly the first step in the mortgage
  satisfaction process.Â  In order for Bostic to recover the statutory penalty
  under section 29-3-320, he had to satisfy the condition precedent of making a
  â€˜requestâ€™ for [the mortgagee] to record his mortgage as satisfied.â€Â  Id.Â  A request, to trigger the statutory penalty, may not be implied or inferred. Â Id. at 155, 650 S.E.2d at 486.Â  The request must affirmatively convey to the
  mortgagee that a recording of the satisfaction is sought.[3]Â  Id.
The Dykemansâ€™ claim under the
  applicable penal statutory framework similarly fails for lack of an affirmative
  request to have the mortgage recorded as satisfied.Â  The Dykemans may have
  entertained a reasonable expectation that Wells Fargo would satisfy the
  mortgage of record following the payoff.Â  That expectation, however, was
  unstated.Â  Because of the windfall nature of the statutory penalty, we are
  persuaded the Legislature did not intend to invoke the statutory penalty in the
  absence of a clear, affirmative request.Â  The Court of Appeals spoke directly
  to this in Kinard v. Fleet Real Estate Funding Corp., 319 S.C. 408, 412,
  461 S.E.2d 833, 835 (Ct. App. 1995).Â  The court in Kinard described two
  statutory interpretation principles, in the context of the applicable statutory
  scheme, when it stated, â€œthe proposition that penal
  statutes must be strictly construed, especially when the penalty may result in
  a windfall to a plaintiffâ€ and â€œthe proposition that the requirements of a
  penal statute must be applied in a manner which results in fairness and justice
  to the parties.â€Â  Id.Â  A fair and balanced consideration of this penal
  statutory scheme leads us to conclude that an implied request does not satisfy sections
  29-3-310 and 320.[4]
We hold that section 29-3-310 requires the following elements be
  established by the mortgagor to trigger the substantial penalty and related
  relief in section 29-3-320: (1) that he has made full payment of his â€œdebts,â€
  including any applicable â€œdamages, costs, and chargesâ€; (2) that he has made a
  â€œrequest by certified mail or other form of deliveryâ€[5] that the mortgage be satisfied of
  record; (3) that he has made a â€œtender of fees of office for entering
  satisfactionâ€; and (4) that the mortgagee has failed to â€œenter satisfaction in
  the proper office on the mortgageâ€ within three months of the request.[6]
III.
Because the Dykemans have failed to establish the
  element of a request under sections 29-3-310 and 320, the trial court properly
  entered summary judgment for Wells Fargo.
AFFIRMED.
TOAL, C.J.,
  WALLER, PLEICONES and BEATTY, JJ., concur.


[1]  Following
  a real estate refinancing, the standard cover letter from a closing attorney to
  the holder of the mortgage usually includes the payment due on the debt and any
  fee necessary to enter a satisfaction of the mortgage in the proper office.Â 
  Such standard cover letters may include an affirmative request that the
  mortgagee cause a satisfaction to be entered of record.Â  We recognize, however,
  that in some circumstances, the mortgagee may enlist the closing attorney to
  accomplish the task of ensuring that the mortgage satisfaction is properly
  entered.Â  See Kinard v. Fleet Real Estate Funding Corp., 319 S.C.
  408, 410, 461 S.E.2d 833, 834 (Ct. App. 1995).
[2]  This action was brought by the Dykemans â€œon
  behalf of themselves and those similarly situated.â€
[3]  Bostic additionally involved an allegation of telephone conversations between the
  parties shortly after the payoff check was mailed.Â  Id. at 155, 650
  S.E.2d at 485.Â  It appears the record was scant in this regard, and the court
  declined to conclude for summary judgment purposes that these purported phone
  conversations be construed as a â€œrequest.â€Â  Id. at 155-56, 650 S.E.2d at
  485-86.Â  In the case before us, the Dykemans rely exclusively on their
  compliance with the â€œborrowerâ€™s responsibilitiesâ€ document furnished by Wells
  Fargo. Â (As alleged in the Dykemansâ€™ second amended complaint, â€œ[t]he payment
  and delivery of the $5.00 fee by [the Dykemans] . . . pursuant to [Wells
  Fargoâ€™s] demand therefore as a condition to filing a satisfaction of mortgage
  constituted a request.â€)Â  We therefore do not reach the question whether a
  verbal request could be sufficient.
[4]  We
  do not suggest that a mortgageeâ€™s conduct is irrelevant in analyzing a
  mortgagorâ€™s compliance with the section 29-3-310 elements.Â  Kinard illustrates this point.Â  319 S.C. at 412-13, 461 S.E.2d at 835 (holding the
  mortgagorâ€™s remittal of fees to the mortgagorâ€™s attorney constituted a tender of
  fees under the statute because the mortgagee agreed to have the attorney record
  the satisfaction).Â  Thus, there may be situations when a mortgagor may properly
  rely on the conduct of a mortgage company to support the finding of a request
  under section 29-3-310.Â  We hold the record before us does not present such a
  situation.
[5]  Section
  29-3-310 was amended in 1999 to include the requirement that the request be
  accomplished â€œby certified mail or other form of delivery with a proof of delivery
  . . . .â€
[6]  This case, of course, has drawn our attention
  to the request element.Â  As discussed, the mortgagor must make the request, and
  under the facts presented, we do not imply a request by the mortgagor from the
  mortgageeâ€™s representations in the â€œborrowerâ€™s responsibilitiesâ€ document.Â  Our
  holding today should not be construed as foreclosing all relief to a mortgagor
  in this circumstance.Â  When a mortgagee, for valuable consideration, represents
  that it will perform in a particular manner, and then fails to perform as
  promised, a traditional action may be available.Â  In such circumstance, a
  mortgagor may pursue an action by alleging and proving the existence of a duty;
  breach of that duty; and damages proximately caused by the breach. Â A claim
  under sections 29-3-310 and 320 is clearly more appealing to mortgagors with
  its windfall penalty and accompanying absence of the usual burden of having to
  prove proximate cause and damages.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court

	
		
			
				David H.
      Barton, Employee, Claimant,
			
		
	

v.

	
		
			
				William Ian
      Higgs d/b/a Iyanel Enterprises and Total Home Exteriors, Inc., Employers, and
      Key Risk Insurance and SC Uninsured Employers Fund, Carrier, Defendants,
				Of Whom Total
      Home Exteriors, Inc., Employers, and Key Risk Insurance are the Respondents,
				and SC
      Uninsured Employers Fund is the Petitioner.
			
		
	


ON WRIT OF CERTIORARI TO THE COURT OF
  APPEALS

Appeal from Greenville County
Â D. Garrison Hill, Circuit Court Judge
Opinion No. 26594
Heard November 18, 2008 - Filed February
  9, 2009Â Â  
REVERSED


	
		
			
				Amy V. Cofield, of Lexington, and Latonya Dilligard
  Edwards, of Columbia, for Petitioner.
				David
  A. Wilson and Michael A. Farry, both of Horton, Drawdy, Ward & Jenkins, of Greenville, for Respondents.
			
		
	


CHIEF JUSTICE TOAL:Â Â Â Â  In this workersâ€™ compensation case, the court of appeals held
  that Petitioner South Carolina Uninsured Employersâ€™ Fund (the Fund) was
  responsible for paying benefits to an injured employee.Â  Barton v. Higgs,
  372 S.C. 109, 641 S.E.2d 39 (Ct. App. 2007).Â  We granted a writ of certiorari
  to review that decision and now reverse.

Factual/Procedural
  Background
David Barton (Claimant) was employed by William Higgs
  d/b/a Iyanel Enterprises (Iyanel), which served as the roofing subcontractor
  for Respondent Total Home Exteriors (Total Home).Â  On November 22, 2003,
  Claimant sustained a compensable injury when he fell from a roof.Â  At the time
  of the accident, Iyanel did not have workersâ€™ compensation insurance, and thus,
  as the higher-tier contractor, Total Home remained liable to pay Claimant
  benefits.Â  Total Home sought to transfer liability to the Fund pursuant to S.C.
  Code Ann. Â§ 42-1-415 (Supp. 2007).Â  
At the hearing
  before the single commissioner, the president of Total Home testified that he
  received a Certificate of Insurance from Higgs showing that Iyanel had a
  workers compensation policy in effect from September 13, 2003 through September
  13, 2004.Â  The Certificate listed Total Home as the certificate holder and
  Jackie Perry Insurance Agency (Insurance Company) as the producer, but the Certificate
  was not signed in the blank listed for â€œAuthorized Representative.â€Â Â  Â Higgs
  testified that he paid for the workersâ€™ compensation insurance and that an
  employee of the Insurance Company issued the Certificate of Insurance.Â 
  Nonetheless, coverage was never bound, resulting in Iyanel not being insured on
  the date of the accident.Â  
The single
  commissioner found that Iyanel had attempted in good faith to obtain workersâ€™
  compensation insurance and presented the Certificate of Insurance to Total
  Home, upon which Total Home relied in good faith.Â  Accordingly, the single
  commissioner ruled that liability should be transferred to the Fund.Â  The full
  commission, the circuit court, and the court of appeals affirmed the single
  commissionerâ€™s decision to transfer liability. 
We granted a writ
  of certiorari and the Fund presents the following issue for review:

	Did the
  court of appeals err in affirming the decision to transfer liability to the
  Fund pursuant to Â§ 42-1-415?

Standard
  of Review
When reviewing an
  appeal from the workersâ€™ compensation commission, the appellate court may not
  weigh the evidence or substitute its judgment for that of the full commission
  as to the weight of evidence on questions of fact.Â  Therrell v. Jerryâ€™s Inc., 370 S.C. 22, 26, 633 S.E.2d 893, 894-95 (2006).Â 
  However, the appellate court may reverse the full commissionâ€™s decision if it
  is based on an error of law.Â  Id.Â  The issue of
  interpretation of a statute is a question of law for the Court.Â  Catawba Indian Tribe of South Carolina v. State, 372
  S.C. 519, 524, 642 S.E.2d 751, 753 (2007).
Law/Analysis
The Fund argues
  that the court of appeals erred in affirming the decision to transfer liability
  because the Certificate of Insurance was unsigned.Â  We agree.Â  
Under
  the Workersâ€™ Compensation Act, a general contractor is considered the
  â€œstatutory employerâ€ of a subcontractorâ€™s employees and is liable to pay
  workersâ€™ compensation benefits to the subcontractorâ€™s employee injured on the
  job.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 42-1-410 (2006).Â  Thus, â€œ[t]he employee of the sub-contractor may look to the prime
  contractor for workersâ€™ compensation benefits without regard to whether the
  sub-contractor is covered by a workersâ€™ compensation insurance policy.â€Â  Freeman Mechanical, Inc. v. J.W. Bateson Co., Inc., 316
  S.C. 95, 97, 447 S.E.2d 197, 198 (1994).Â 
  The purpose of this statute is to protect the employee and assure coverage in
  the event of an injury.Â  
In
  1996, however, the Legislature created a narrow exception to this rule which
  provides that the general contractor may transfer the responsibility to pay
  benefits:

	[U]pon the submission of documentation to the commission that a
  contractor or subcontractor has represented himself to a higher tier
  subcontractor, contractor, or project owner as having workersâ€™ compensation
  insurance at the time the contractor or subcontractor was engaged to perform
  work, the higher tier subcontractor, contractor, or project owner must be
  relieved of any and all liability under this title except as specifically
  provided in this section.

Section 42-1-415(A).Â  However, to transfer liability to the
  Fund, the higher-tier contractor â€œmust collect documentation
  of insurance . . . on a standard form acceptable to the commission.â€Â  The
  workersâ€™ compensation commission has promulgated a regulation providing that a
  Certificate of Insurance â€œshall serve as documentation of insuranceâ€ and that
  the Certificate â€œmust be dated, signed, and issued by an authorized
  representative of the insurance carrier for the insured.â€Â  S.C.
  Code Reg. 67-415 (Supp. 2007).Â  In other words, liability may be transferred
  from the higher tier contractor to the Fund only after the higher tier
  contractor has properly documented the subcontractorâ€™s claim that it retains
  workersâ€™ compensation insurance.Â  This statutory scheme provides an ultimate
  safety net for general contractors against a subcontractorâ€™s act of fraud.

In
  the instant case, by failing to collect a signed Certificate of Insurance form,
  Total Home failed to meet the requirement as set forth in the regulation.Â  Even
  assuming Iyanel was not acting fraudulently in submitting the unsigned form, Total
  Home could have easily investigated the absence of the signature and determined
  that Iyanel did not have a valid policy.Â  In our view, public funds should not
  be expended where Respondent could have discovered the mistake by acting in accordance
  with the regulations.
We recognize that the full
  commission found that the form was a valid documentation and, as the agency
  charged with administering the Workersâ€™ Compensation Act, this decision should
  be given great deference.Â  See Dunton v. S.C. Bd.
    of Examâ€™rs in Optometry, 291 S.C. 221,
  223, 353 S.E.2d 132, 133 (1987) (recognizing that the construction of a statute by the agency charged with its
  administration will be accorded the most respectful consideration).Â  However, we
  hold that the full commissionâ€™s decision should not be upheld because
  the interpretation is clearly contrary to its own regulation.Â  See Brown v. South Carolina Depâ€™t of Health and
    Envtl. Control, 348
  S.C. 507, 560 S.E.2d 410 (2002) (holding that while
  the Court typically defers to an agencyâ€™s construction of its own regulation,
  where the plain language of the regulation is contrary to the agencyâ€™s
  interpretation, the Court will reject the interpretation).
Conclusion
For the foregoing reasons, we reverse the decision of the court of
  appeals and hold that Total Home may not transfer liability to the Fund.Â  
KITTREDGE, J., and Acting Justices James E. Moore and Donna S.
  Strom, concur. WALLER, J., dissenting in a separate opinion.

JUSTICE WALLER:Â  I respectfully dissent.Â  In my opinion,
  the Court of Appeals correctly held that respondent
  Total Home â€œmet all of the statutory requirements to transfer liability.â€ Â Barton
    v. Higgs, 372 S.C. 109, 117, 641 S.E.2d 39, 43 (Ct. App. 2007).Â 
  Accordingly, I would affirm
  in result. 
S.C.
  Code Ann. Â§ 42-1-415 provides that when a subcontractor â€œhas represented
  himselfâ€ to a general contractor as having workersâ€™ compensation insurance at
  the time the subcontractor â€œwas engaged to perform work,â€ the general contractor
  â€œmust be relieved of any and all liability.â€Â  The statute further states that
  the general contractor â€œmust collect documentation of insurance â€¦ on a standard
  form acceptable to the commission.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 42-1-415 (Supp. 2008).
A
  review of some additional facts is in order.Â  The president for Total Home
  testified that he would not have given Iyanel Enterprises a contract without
  obtaining a certificate of workersâ€™ compensation insurance.Â  Likewise, the
  testimony of William Higgs confirmed that before Iyanel could work as a
  subcontractor on jobs for Total Home, Total Home required him to get a
  certificate of insurance.Â  According to Higgs, he went to the Jackie Perry
  Insurance Agency, paid his money for the policy, and obtained the certificate.Â 
  Despite the issuance of the certificate by the Perry Agency, the coverage was
  never bound, resulting in Iyanel not being insured on the date of Claimantâ€™s
  accident.
The
  record reflects that the Perry Agency had employed someone who issued
  certificates of insurance without the coverage being bound.Â  Therefore, the
  only fraud that seems to have occurred in this case is by an employee of the
  insurance agency, not by the subcontractor.Â  Although the majority concedes
  that section 42-1-415 is designed to protect a general contractor from fraud,
  the end result of the majorityâ€™s reasoning is that Total Home becomes a victim
  of fraud simply because it was not committed by the subcontractor.
More
  importantly, however, the majority seems to gloss over the fact that the express
  requirements of the statute clearly were met in the instant case.Â  Instead, the
  majority opinion focuses its attention on the regulationâ€™s requirements.[1]Â 
  This runs contrary to settled precedent.Â  
Although
  regulations authorized by the Legislature generally have the force of law, a
  regulation may not alter or add to a statute.Â  Goodman v. City of Columbia, 318 S.C. 488, 490, 458 S.E.2d 531, 532 (1995); Banks v. Batesburg
    Hauling Co., 24 S.E.2d 496, 499 (1943); see also Society
      of Profâ€™l Journalists v. Sexton, 283 S.C. 563, 567, 324 S.E.2d 313,
  315 (1984) (â€œAlthough a regulation has the force of law, it must fall when
  it alters or adds to a statute.â€).
The Goodman case is instructive.Â  Goodman involved S.C. Code Â§ 42-17-50, the
  workersâ€™ compensation statute which allows â€œan application for reviewâ€ of the
  single commissionerâ€™s order by the Full Commission.Â  The Commission promulgated
  Regulation 67-701 which requires that a specific form be filed (Form 30).Â  The
  petitioner in Goodman did not file a Form 30, but instead wrote the Commission a letter â€œexpressing his desire to appeal.â€Â  Goodman, 318 S.C. at 490, 458 S.E.2d at 532.Â  On direct appeal, the
  Court of Appeals found the petitionerâ€™s letter did not substantially comply
  with section 42-17-50.Â  
On
  certiorari, this Court reversed.Â  The Goodman court stated that Regulation
  67-701 â€œadds the requirement of applying for review with
  a particular form, thereby adding to the statute. Â Insofar as Reg. 67-701
    increases the threshold requirements of section 42-17-50, the specifications
    set forth in the statute must prevail.â€Â  Id. at 490-491, 458 S.E.2d at
  532 (emphasis added).Â  The Court in Goodman therefore held that that petitionerâ€™s letter constituted substantial compliance
  with section 42-17-50.Â  Id. at 491, 458 S.E.2d at 532.
The
  instant case is analogous to Goodman in that there was substantial
  compliance with the applicable statute.Â  Total Home requested and received
  documentation of Iyanelâ€™s insurance on a form authorized by the Commission.Â 
  All the substantive parts of the form were filled in - it listed Higgs as being
  insured with a workersâ€™ compensation policy (including a policy number and
  coverage dates), and also listed Total Home as the certificate holder.Â  
The
  only thing missing was a signature.Â  In my opinion, requiring such strict
  compliance with the regulation would only serve to frustrate legislative
  intent.[2]Â 
  The obvious purpose of section 42-1-415 is to encourage a higher tier
  contractor to require proof that its subcontractors carry workersâ€™ compensation
  insurance.Â  Therefore, if the higher tier contractor substantially complies
  with the document collection requirement, it should not be ultimately liable
  when the subcontractor turns out to not actually be insured.Â  See Â§42-1-415; Goodman, supra.
In
  addition, nowhere in the statute is there a requirement that the higher tier
  contractor verify the authenticity of the documentation of insurance.Â 
  Nevertheless, the majority suggests that Total Home â€œcould have easily
  investigated the absence of the signature and determined that Iyanel did not
  have a valid policy.â€Â  First, I disagree that section 42-1-415 imposes this
  burden on the general contractor.Â  Moreover, I also disagree that under the
  facts of this case, any such investigation would have uncovered the fraud
  apparently committed by a rogue employee of the insurance agency.[3] 
Put simply, the majorityâ€™s focus on the absence of a signature literally â€œelevat[es] form over substance.â€
  Â South Carolina Second Injury Fund v. American Yard Prods., 330 S.C. 20, 24, 496 S.E.2d 862, 864 (1998). Â At the very least, the majority has elevated
  regulation over statute, and in my opinion, this runs contrary to well-settled
  law.Â  See, e.g., Goodman, supra; Society of
    Profâ€™l Journalists v. Sexton, supra.
In sum, because I believe the majority opinion overlooks precedent
  which stands for the principle that a regulation should not trump the language
  and intent of the statute, I respectfully dissent.


[1] The Fundâ€™s sole argument, with which the majority
  agrees, is that because the form was unsigned, it did not meet the
  requirements of the applicable regulation.Â  Regulation 67-415 provides the
  following information about the term â€œdocumentation of insuranceâ€ used in the
  statute:

	For purposes of Section 42-1-415, the ACORD Form 25-S,
  Certificate of Insurance, as published by the ACORD Corporation and as issued
  by the insurance carrier for the insured, shall serve as documentation of
  insurance.Â  The Certificate of Insurance must be dated, signed, and issued by
  an authorized representative of the insurance carrier for the insured.

S.C. Code Reg.
  67-415(A) (Supp. 2008).Â  The ACORD Form 25-S is a standard insurance industry
  form.
[2] See, e.g., South Carolina Second
  Injury Fund v. American Yard Prods., 330 S.C. 20, 22, 496 S.E.2d 862,
  863 (1998) (this Courtâ€™s primary function when interpreting a statute is
  to ascertain and give effect to the intent of the legislature).Â  
[3] For example, if Total Home had called the Perry
  Agency to verify the unsigned documentation, it is quite possible that the
  employee who was not binding the coverage could have simply lied to cover up
  his/her own fraudulent activity.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court

	
		
			
				The State, Appellant,
				v.
				Jimmy Ramsey, Respondent.
			
		
	


Appeal from York County
Â John C. Hayes III, Circuit Court Judge
Opinion No. 26595
Heard October 8, 2008 - Filed February 9,
  2009Â  
REVERSED AND REMANDED


	
		
			
				Attorney
  General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant
  Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, and Senior Assistant Attorney
  General Harold M. Coombs, Jr., all of Columbia, for Appellant.
				Christopher
  A. Wellborn, of Rock Hill, for Respondent.
			
		
	


CHIEF JUSTICE
  TOAL:Â  In this case, the magistrate
  held a probable cause hearing on Respondent Jimmy Ramseyâ€™s criminal domestic
  violence (CDV) charge and dismissed it for lack of probable cause.Â  The circuit
  court affirmed the magistrateâ€™s finding.Â  On appeal, the State claims the
  magistrate erred in holding a probable cause hearing and dismissing
  Respondentâ€™s CDV charge.Â  
Factual/Procedural
  Background
On
  February 18, 2006, Respondent was arrested on a warrant for burglary first
  degree and was issued a uniform traffic ticket for CDV first offense.Â  On May
  16, 2006, the circuit court held a preliminary hearing on the burglary charge.Â 
  The circuit court dismissed the burglary charge for lack of probable cause and
  remanded the CDV charge to the magistrate.Â  Respondent filed with the
  magistrate a motion to dismiss the CDV charge for lack of probable cause.Â  On
  August 14, 2006, the magistrate held a hearing to determine probable cause and
  granted Respondentâ€™s motion to dismiss.Â  The State appealed to the circuit
  court.Â  The circuit court affirmed the magistrateâ€™s order of dismissal and the
  State appealed.Â  We certified this case pursuant to Rule 204(b), SCACR.Â  
Issue
Did
  the magistrate have jurisdiction to hold a probable cause hearing on
  Respondentâ€™s charge for criminal domestic violence?
Law/Analysis
In general, magistrates have criminal jurisdiction â€œof all
  offenses which may be subject to the penalties of either fine or forfeiture not
  exceeding five hundred dollars or imprisonment in the jail or workhouse not
  exceeding thirty days.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§
  22-3-550 (2007).Â  For crimes outside magistratesâ€™ jurisdiction, magistrates are
  authorized to conduct a preliminary examination.Â  See Rule 2, SCRCrimP (â€œAny
  defendant charged with a crime not triable by a magistrate shall be brought
  before a magistrate and shall be given notice of his right to a preliminary
  hearing.â€).Â  The
  purpose of a preliminary examination is to determine whether probable cause
  exists to believe that the defendant committed the crime and to warrant the
  defendantâ€™s subsequent trial.Â  12 S.C.
  Jurisprudence Magistrates and Municipal Judges Â§ 31.Â 
  Nevertheless, for those matters within magistratesâ€™ jurisdiction, preliminary
  determinations of probable cause are not authorized by statute.Â  Indeed, South Carolina law requires that all magistrate
  proceedings â€œshall be summary or with only such delay as a fair and just
  examination of the case requires.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 22-3-730 (2007).Â  
In
  the present case, Respondent was charged with criminal domestic violence, first
  offense, pursuant to Section 16-25-20 of the South Carolina Code, which provides
  that the offense â€œmust be tried in summary court.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 16-25-20
  (2007).Â  Prior to ruling on the merits, the magistrate found that Section
  22-5-710 of the South Carolina Code gave him the authority to hold preliminary
  examinations in criminal cases.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 22-5-710 (2008).Â  We
  disagree, and hold that the magistrate did not have the authority to hold a
  preliminary hearing in this matter.Â  Â 
Section
  22-5-710, relied upon by the magistrate, grants â€œmagistrates in counties where
  a county court has been establishedâ€ the authority to conduct a preliminary
  hearing â€œas is provided by law in criminal cases beyond the jurisdiction of
  magistrates.â€Â  Id.Â  This section is inapplicable because South Carolina no longer uses a county court system.Â  However, even if we were to assume
  that the magistrate intended to rely upon the authority granted him by Section
  22-5-320, which empowers magistrates to conduct preliminary hearings upon the
  motion of the defendant on matters beyond their jurisdiction, we must find that
  the magistrate exceeded his authority.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 22-5-320
  (2008).Â  The CDV charge was within the magistrateâ€™s jurisdiction, and we find there
  is no authority for the proposition that magistrates are authorized to conduct
  preliminary hearings on matters within their own trial jurisdiction.Â  To hold
  otherwise would undermine the summary nature of magistrate proceedings and
  unduly expand magistrate dockets.Â  
Accordingly,
  we hold that the magistrate judge should have declined Respondentâ€™s request for
  a probable cause hearing and instead brought the charge to trial for summary
  disposition.Â  The trial court therefore erred in considering the merits of the
  probable cause inquiry and affirming the magistrate.Â  
Conclusion
For the foregoing reasons,
  we hereby reverse and remand this case to the magistrate for summary
  disposition.Â 


WALLER,
  PLEICONES, BEATTY and KITTREDGE, JJ., concur.
