THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court

	
		
			
				Jennifer Marie
      Harris, Appellant,
				v.
				Anderson County
      Sheriffâ€™s Office, Respondent.
			
		
	


Appeal From Anderson County
James C. Williams, Circuit Court Judge
Opinion No. 26596
Heard November 5, 2008 - Filed February 9,
  2009Â Â  
REVERSED AND REMANDED


	
		
			
				R.
  Lawton McIntosh, of McIntosh, Sherard & Sullivan, of Anderson, for
  Appellant.
				Wm.
  Douglas Gray, of McNair Law Firm, of Anderson, for Respondent.
			
		
	


JUSTICE
  KITTREDGE:  This appeal requires
  the Court to construe section 47-3-110 of the South Carolina Code (1987), the
  so-called dog bite statute.Â  The narrow question before us is the meaning of
  the term â€œorâ€ in section 47-3-110.Â  The broader question requires us to discern
  the degree, if any, to which the Legislature retained the application of common
  law principles in section 47-3-110. Â Â Â 
In
  construing the term â€œorâ€ consistent with its common understanding as a
  disjunctive, we hold section 47-3-110 allows a plaintiff to pursue a statutory
  claim against the owner of the dog â€œor other person having the dog in his care
  or keeping.â€Â  Because of the plain language in this statute, we conclude that
  the Legislature intended to allow a claim against the owner of the dog when another
  person has the dog in his care or keeping.Â  Moreover, in light of the trial
  courtâ€™s determination that statutory liability against a dog owner
  fundamentally rests on negligence concepts, we address the common law remnant
  retained in section 47-3-110.Â  For the reasons set forth below, we reverse the grant
  of summary judgment to the Anderson County Sheriffâ€™s Office and remand for
  trial.Â  
I. 
Deputy
  Todd Caron of the Anderson County Sheriffâ€™s Office kenneled his police dog
  (Sleuber) at the Happistance Veterinary Clinic (clinic) in Townville, South Carolina, while he was on vacation.Â  Sleuber had a recent history of multiple
  unprovoked attacks, a history well known to Deputy Caron and the sheriffâ€™s
  office.Â  Jennifer Harris worked at the clinic as a veterinary assistant.Â  While
  kenneled at the clinic, Sleuber attacked Harris, severely injuring her.Â  It is
  undisputed that Harris did not provoke the attack.Â  
Harris
  pursued workersâ€™ compensation benefits from her employer, the clinic. Â Harris subsequently
  filed this lawsuit against the sheriffâ€™s office, asserting claims under section
  47-3-110 and negligence.Â  Cross-motions for summary judgment were filed.Â  The
  circuit court focused on the statutory claim and, with respect to a dog ownerâ€™s
  liability, read negligence principles into the statute.Â  The circuit court
  reasoned that the sheriffâ€™s office was no longer in control of its police dog
  (and should not be held responsible) once care of the dog was relinquished to
  the clinic. In granting the sheriffâ€™s office summary judgment, the circuit
  court held that when a dog owner leaves his dog in the care of another, section
  47-3-110 only permits a claim against the â€œother person having the dog in his
  care or keeping.â€Â  Harris appealed, and we granted Rule 204(b), SCACR,
  certification. Â 
II.Â  
Summary judgment is
  governed by Rule 56, SCRCP. Â Summary judgment is appropriate when there is no
  genuine issue of material fact and the moving party is entitled to judgment as
  a matter of law.Â  Our review is plenary, however, for we are presented with a question
  of statutory interpretation.Â  Town of Summerville v. City of N. Charleston, 378 S.C. 107, 110, 662 S.E.2d 40, 41 (2008).Â  
III.Â  
A.
We begin our
  analysis with this Courtâ€™s decision in Hossenlopp v. Cannon, 285 S.C.
  367, 329 S.E.2d 438 (1985).Â  In Hossenlopp, the Court was presented with
  a common law negligence claim arising from injuries caused by a dog.Â  At the
  time, South Carolina adhered to what was commonly referred to as the â€œone free
  biteâ€ rule.Â  The â€œone free biteâ€ rule imposed common law liability against a
  dog owner only when the owner knew or should have known of the dogâ€™s vicious
  propensities, that is, there was no liability for the first bite.Â  In Hossenlopp,
  under our policy making role in the common law, we rejected the â€œone free biteâ€
  rule and imposed quasi-strict liability on dog owners by adopting the â€œCalifornia
  Ruleâ€ for dog bite liability.Â  This shift in the common law is reflected in the 
Hossenlopp Courtâ€™s adoption of the following jury instruction:

	The law of California provides that the owner of any dog which
  bites a person while such person is on or in a public place or is lawfully on
  or in a private place, including the property of the owner of such dog, is
  liable for such damages as may be suffered by the person bitten regardless of
  whether or not the dog previously had been vicious, regardless of the ownerâ€™s
  knowledge or lack of knowledge of any such viciousness, and regardless of
  whether or not the owner has been negligent in respect to the dog, provided,
  however, that if a person knowingly and voluntarily invites attack upon himself
  [herself], or if, when on the property of the dog owner, a person voluntarily,
  knowingly, and without reasonable necessity, exposes himself [herself] to the
  danger, the owner of the dog is not liable for the consequences.

Id. at
  372, 329 S.E.2d at 441.
Hossenlopp represents the last time the Court addressed a dog
  bite case in a purely common law setting. Â The following year, 1986, the Legislature
  enacted section 47-3-110:

	Whenever
  any person is bitten or otherwise attacked by a dog while the person is in a
  public place or is lawfully in a private place, including the property of the
  owner of the dog or other person having the dog in his care or keeping, the
  owner of the dog or other person having the dog in his care or keeping is
  liable for the damages suffered . . . .Â  If a person provokes a dog into
  attacking him then the owner of the dog is not liable.Â  

Section
  47-3-110 was enacted in response to Hossenlopp.Â  This transition from
  the common law to the statutory setting, of course, restricts our policy making
  role and concomitantly requires this Court to discern legislative intent. The juxtaposition
  of Hossenlopp to section 47-3-110 does, however, provide a strong frame
  of reference for ascertaining legislative intent. Â Section 47-3-110 retained Hossenloppâ€™s
  strict liability against dog owners and additionally imposed liability on any
  other persons having the dog in their â€œcare or keeping.â€ 

B.
â€œThe
  cardinal rule of statutory construction is to ascertain and effectuate the
  intent of the [L]egislature.â€Â  Hodges v. Rainey, 341 S.C. 79, 85, 533
  S.E.2d 578, 581 (2000).Â  The Court will give words their plain and ordinary
  meaning, and will not resort to a subtle or forced construction that would
  limit or expand the statuteâ€™s operation.Â  Auto Owners Ins. Co. v. Rollison,
  378 S.C. 600, 609, 663 S.E.2d 484, 488 (2008). Â The Legislature unmistakably
  adopted a strict liability approach for injuries caused by dogs, save the
  situation when the injured party provoked the attack.Â  Traditional principles
  of statutory construction bolster this interpretation.
In
  light of the remedial nature of the statute, and its plain language, we find
  the Legislature intended the word â€œorâ€ in accordance with its common,
  disjunctive usage. Â Brewer v. Brewer, 242 S.C. 9, 14, 129 S.E.2d 736,
  738 (1963) (noting that the use of the word â€œorâ€ in a statute â€œis a disjunctive
  particle that marks an alternativeâ€); see also Rollison, 378 S.C. at
  609, 663 S.E.2d at 488 (observing that â€œâ€˜[a] statute remedial in nature should
  be liberally construed in order to accomplish the object[ive] soughtâ€™â€ (quoting Inabinet v. Royal Exch. Assurance of London, 165 S.C. 33, 36, 162 S.E.
  599, 600 (1932))).Â  Â Â 
To
  construe the term â€œorâ€ in an atypical manner, limiting the statutory claim of
  Harris to the clinic, would be inconsistent with the remedial and strict
  liability underpinnings of the statute.Â  With the singular exception for the
  circumstance where the injured person provokes the attack, the Legislature has
  chosen to impose strict liability against dog owners and others having â€œthe dog
  in [their] care or keeping.â€Â  Â§ 47-3-110 (â€œ[T]he owner of the dog or other
  person having the dog in his care or keeping is liable for the damages suffered
  . . . .â€). 
Strict
  liability is a policy decision to impose liability regardless of fault.Â 
  Relieving the dog owner of liability where the dog was in the care or keeping
  of another would be contrary to the statutory language and run counter to the
  manifest legislative intent of strict liability.Â  Given the unambiguous
  language, allowing a plaintiff to sue either the owner of the dog or the party
  who assumes the care or keeping of the dog is entirely consistent with a
  logical construction of section 47-3-110.Â  Investor Premium Corp. v. S.C.
    Tax Commâ€™n, 260 S.C. 13, 20, 193 S.E.2d 642, 645 (1973) (setting forth the Courtâ€™s
  function in discerning legislative intent to interpret words in a statute in a
  way that both gives meaning to the use of the word and is logical). 
The
  use of the term â€œorâ€ in section 47-3-110 does not mandate a forced selection
  for an injured party.Â  With the one exception noted in the statute, the owner
  of the dog is subject to liability for injuries caused by his dog.Â  Where the
  person is injured while the dog is in the care or keeping of someone who is not
  the dogâ€™s owner, the injured party may pursue a statutory claim against the
  owner of the dog or the other person having the dog in his care or keeping.Â  
C.
The
  dog owner posits two basic arguments to sustain the grant of summary judgment
  in its favor.Â  First, we are asked to adopt the reasoning of the circuit court
  which overlaid negligence principles on section 47-3-110â€™s imposition of
  liability on a dog owner.Â  The circuit court essentially found that the dog
  owner was no longer in control (and hence not at-fault) once the dog was left
  at the veterinary clinic.Â  While the statute does implicate considerations of
  control with respect to the â€œother person having the dog in his care or keeping,â€
  there is no such limitation with respect to the dog owner.Â  Imposing a control
  requirement or other negligence principles by judicial fiat on the dog owner
  would impose requirements nowhere found in the statute.[1]
Second,
  the dog owner invites the Court, on policy grounds, to create a â€œkennel worker
  exception,â€ and preclude that class of people from asserting statutory strict
  liability claims against a dog owner.Â  See Priebe v. Nelson, 140
  P.3d 848, 861 (Cal. 2006) (recognizing a â€œkennel exceptionâ€ and precluding a
  kennel worker from maintaining a claim against the owner of a dog when injured
  by the dog while in the performance of his duties as a kennel worker).Â  Because
  we are confronted with a matter of statutory interpretation, such policy
  decisions rest exclusively in the Legislature.Â  We are constrained therefore to
  decline the invitation to create a policy exception to section 47-3-110.Â 
  Similarly, we acknowledge that application of section 47-3-110â€™s strict
  liability against dog owners may appear harsh and have unintended
  consequences.Â  But again, such concerns now lie in the Legislature.Â  
D.
Because
  of the dog ownerâ€™s reliance on, and the trial courtâ€™s acceptance of, negligence
  principles to determine statutory liability against a dog owner, we address the
  limited interplay between section 47-3-110 and the common law.Â  We broach this
  subject for the benefit of the bench and bar, as some adhere to the belief that
  section 47-3-110 liability against a dog owner incorporates negligence
  principles.Â  This belief, while erroneous, is understandable in light of the
  statutorily imposed liability against those who undertake to provide the care
  or keeping of a dog.Â  
The
  Legislatureâ€™s use of the phrase â€œcare or keepingâ€ clearly requires that the
  â€œother personâ€ act in a manner which manifests an acceptance of responsibility
  for the care or keeping of the dog.Â  To this degree, the Legislature retained the
  common law principle of duty in determining the liability of the â€œother
  person.â€Â  An example of this relationship between section 47-3-110 and the
  common law is illustrated in the case of Nesbitt v. Lewis, 335 S.C. 441,
  517 S.E.2d 11 (Ct. App. 1999).Â  
Nesbitt involved an unprovoked attack by dogs on a child who
  was lawfully on private property.Â  The property was owned by three persons, a
  mother and her two adult children, a son and a daughter.Â  The mother owned the
  dogs, and she lived on the property with her son.Â  The mother was liable under
  the statute simply as a result of owning the dogs.Â  The added feature of owning
  the property and exercising control over the premises, in tandem with providing
  the care and keeping of the dogs, was a further basis on which to impose
  liability against the mother.
The son
  was liable under the statute as a property owner who exercised control over the
  premises.Â  As concerns the statutory element of â€œcare or keeping,â€ the son
  â€œlived with [his mother] at the time of the attack and . . . tended [to] the
  dogs, taking them to the veterinarian, feeding them, and playing with them on
  occasion.â€Â  Id. at 446, 517 S.E.2d at 14.
The
  daughter was the third property owner.Â  She â€œhad lived elsewhere for over five
  years.â€ Â The daughter â€œdid not take care of the dogs . . . Â [and she did] not
  exercise control over the premises . . . .â€ Â Id. Â The Nesbitt court reversed a jury verdict against the daughter, noting that the â€œevidence
  precludes a finding that [she] owned the dogs or had them in her care or
  keeping.â€Â  Id. at 447, 517 S.E.2d at 14.Â  The daughter was not liable
  under the statute for the dog attack, for â€œshe lacked possession and control
  over [her motherâ€™s] house and the dogs.â€ Id. at 446, 517 S.E.2d at 14. Â In
  short, the daughter owed no duty of care to the injured party.Â  The Nesbitt court correctly invoked common law concepts in analyzing and determining the
  liability of a property owner who does not own the dog which caused the injury.
Nesbitt, thus, presents three scenarios under section
  47-3-110 when the attack is unprovoked and the injured party is lawfully on the
  premises.Â  First, the dog owner is strictly liable and common law principles
  are not implicated.Â  Second, a property owner is liable when he exercises
  control over, and assumes responsibility for, the care and keeping of the dog.Â 
  Third, a property owner is not liable under the statute when he has no control of
  the premises and provides no care or keeping of the dog.Â  It is the presence or
  absence of a duty that determines liability in the latter two situations that involve
  a statutory claim against the â€œother person having the dog in his care or
  keeping.â€Â  To this degree, section 47-3-110 implicates the common law.[2]Â 
  Our Legislature has spoken clearly in section 47-3-110 that, as concerns a dog
  ownerâ€™s liability, negligence principles in general and fault in particular
  have no place.Â  Â Â Â Â 
E.
We
  recognize there remain unanswered questions concerning section 47-3-110.Â 
  Merely by way of example, we can envision questions arising with regard to
  principles of indemnification and third party practice under Rule 14, SCRCP.Â  We
  leave these questions for another day.Â  Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â 
IV.
Construing
  the language of section 47-3-110, and discerning legislative intent, we hold
  that a person injured by a dog may pursue a claim against the owner of the dog
  when the injury occurs while the dog is in the care or keeping of another.Â Â  The
  Legislature has made a policy decision to hold dog owners strictly liable when the
  dog bites or otherwise attacks a person who is lawfully on the premises, except
  when the injured person provoked the attack.Â  The Legislature has further
  statutorily imposed liability on those who assume the care or keeping of a
  dog.Â  The grant of summary judgment in favor of the Anderson County Sheriffâ€™s
  Office is reversed and the matter is remanded to the circuit court for trial.
REVERSED
  AND REMANDED.
TOAL, C.J.,
  WALLER and BEATTY, JJ., concur.Â  PLEICONES, J., concurs in the holding.


[1]  One rule of statutory construction allows the
  Court to deviate from a statuteâ€™s plain language when the result would be so
  patently absurd that it is clear that the Legislature could not have intended
  such a result. State ex rel. McLeod v. Montgomery, 244 S.C. 308, 314,
  136 S.E.2d 778, 782 (1964) (â€œHowever plain the ordinary meaning of the words
  used in a statute may be, the courts will reject that meaning, when to accept
  it would lead to a result so plainly absurd that it could not possibly have
  been intended by the Legislature, or would defeat the plain legislative
  intention; and if possible will construe the statute so as to escape the
  absurdity and carry the intention into effect.â€ (quoting Stackhouse v.
    Rowland, 86 S.C. 419, 422, 68 S.E. 561, 562 (1910))).Â  While we may be concerned with the unintended
  consequences of applying the clear meaning of section 47-3-110 in every
  conceivable circumstance, such concerns in this case fall far short of an
  absurdity that would warrant applying this rule of statutory construction.Â  We
  decline to construe the statute in a manner to shield this dog owner from
  liability, for the imposition of strict liability under section 47-3-110
  reflects a permissible policy determination of the Legislature. 
[2]  We do not suggest that the â€œother personâ€ for
  section 47-3-110 purposes must always be a property owner.Â  There may well be
  circumstances where a person (who is not the dog owner) has the care or keeping
  of a dog and property ownership is not relevant.Â

In The Supreme Court

	
		
			
				In the Matter of Former Calhoun Falls Municipal 
				Court Judge Clinton J. Hall, II, Respondent.

  2009
PUBLIC REPRIMAND


	
		
			
				Senior
  Assistant Attorney General James G. Bogle, Jr., of Columbia, for Commission on

				Clinton
  H. Hall, II, of Due West, pro se Respondent.
			
		
	


PER
  CURIAM: Â In this judicial
  disciplinary matter, the Commission on
  Judicial Conduct (the Commission) instituted this proceeding against then Calhoun Falls municipal court judge Clinton J. Hall, II (Respondent).Â  We find the
  imposition of a public reprimand is warranted.
FACTS
The
  Commission notified Respondent on April 4, 2008 that formal charges had been
  filed against him pursuant to the Rules for Judicial Disciplinary Enforcement
  (RJDE) found in Rule 502 of the South Carolina Appellate Court Rules (SCACR).Â 
  The charges stemmed from the alleged failure of Respondent to meet his
  continuing legal education (CLE) obligations under Rule 510, SCACR, to timely
  file the required annual CLE reports, and to petition this Court for
  reinstatement (following his suspension) before resuming his judicial duties.Â 
  Respondent filed a response to the charges.Â  
A
  hearing was held before a panel of the Commission on July 14, 2008, and a Panel
  Report was issued on August 28, 2008.Â  The panel recommended that Respondent
  receive a public reprimand and that he be required to pay the costs of these
  proceedings.[1]Â 
  In addition, the panel recommended that Respondent be barred from future
  judicial service until he receives explicit written permission from this Court
  to serve.Â  
By
  letter dated September 11, 2008, the Commission forwarded the Panel Report and
  the record to this Court.Â  Neither Disciplinary Counsel nor Respondent has
  filed any exceptions to the Panel Report and the matter is before the Court
  based on the record of the proceedings in this case.
LAW
After a review of the record of the proceedings in this matter, we
  find that by his conduct, Respondent has violated the following provisions of the Code of Judicial
  Conduct contained in Rule 501, SCACR:Â  Canon 1 (upholding the integrity and
  independence of the Judiciary); Canon 1A (stating a judge should participate in
  establishing, maintaining, and enforcing high standards of conduct and shall
  personally observe those standards); Canon 2 (avoiding impropriety and the
  appearance of impropriety); Canon 2A (respecting and complying with the law);
  Canon 3B(2) (exhibiting faithfulness to the law); Canon 3B(8) (disposing of all
  judicial matters promptly, efficiently, and fairly); and Canon 3C(1)
  (diligently discharging judgeâ€™s administrative responsibilities and cooperating
  with other judges and court officials).
In addition, we find Respondent
  has violated the following provisions of the RJDE contained in Rule 502,
  SCACR:Â  Rule 7(a)(1) (violating or attempting to violate the Code of Judicial
  Conduct or the Rules of Professional Conduct or any other applicable ethics
  codes); Rule 7(a)(2) (willfully violating a valid order of the Supreme Court,
  the Commission, or the panels of the Commission or willfully failing to respond
  or appear as required); Rule 7(a)(4) (persistently failing to perform judicial
  duties or persistently performing judicial duties in an incompetent or
  neglectful manner); Rule 7(a)(7) (willfully violating a valid court order); and
  Rule 7(a)(9) (violating the Judgeâ€™s Oath of Office).Â  
CONCLUSION
Respondent
  shall not apply for, seek, or accept any judicial position whatsoever in this
  State without the prior written authorization of this Court after due service
  on the Office of Disciplinary Counsel of any petition seeking the Courtâ€™s
  authorization. Â Respondent is hereby reprimanded for his misconduct and is
  ordered to pay the costs of these proceedings.
PUBLIC REPRIMAND.
TOAL, C.J., WALLER, PLEICONES, BEATTY and KITTREDGE, JJ., concur.


[1]Â  When a judge no longer holds judicial office, a
  public reprimand is the most severe sanction this Court may impose.Â  In re
    Koulpasis, 376 S.C. 496, 657 S.E.2d 759 (2008).

PER
  CURIAM:Â Â  In this attorney disciplinary matter,
  respondent and the Office of Disciplinary Counsel (ODC) have entered into an
  Agreement for Discipline by Consent pursuant to Rule 21, RLDE, Rule 413,
  SCACR.Â  In the Agreement, respondent admits misconduct and consents to any
  sanction up to a definite suspension from the practice of law between nine (9)
  months to one (1) year.Â  See Rule 7, RLDE, Rule 413, SCACR.Â  We accept the Agreement and suspend respondent from the
  practice of law for nine (9) months with conditions for the misconduct reported
in the Agreement.Â  The facts, as set forth in the Agreement, are as follows.Â  
FACTS
On or about December 8, 2007, the Mount
  Pleasant Police Department arrested respondent for possession of a cocaine
  substance.[1]Â 
  Respondent admits that he in fact had possession of the cocaine in his vehicle
  at the time of his arrest.Â  Respondent admits he has a substance abuse problem
  and, further, that substance abuse is a serious problem which impacts all
  aspects of his life, including his fitness to practice law.Â  
Respondent represents he has undergone
  and completed in-patient counseling for substance abuse and has signed a
  contract with Lawyers Helping Lawyers for continuing assistance in dealing with
  his substance abuse.Â  Respondent represents he completed Pretrial Intervention
  and the charges arising out of his December 8, 2007 arrest have been
  dismissed.Â Â Â  
LAW
Respondent
  admits that his misconduct constitutes grounds for discipline under Rule 413,
  RLDE, specifically Rule 7(a)(1) (lawyer shall not violate Rules of Professional
  Conduct or any other rules of this jurisdiction regarding professional conduct
  of lawyers).Â  In addition, respondent admits he has violated the following
  provisions of the Rules of Professional Conduct, Rule 407, SCACR:Â  Rule 8.4(a) (lawyer shall not
    violate Rules of Professional Conduct), Rule 8.4(b) (lawyer shall not commit
    criminal act that reflects adversely on lawyerâ€™s honesty, trustworthiness, or
    fitness to practice law in other respects), Rule 8.4(c) (lawyer shall not commit
    criminal act involving moral turpitude), and Rule 8.4(e) (lawyer shall not
    engage in conduct that is prejudicial to administration of justice).Â  
CONCLUSION
We accept the Agreement for Discipline by
  Consent and suspend respondent from the practice of law for nine (9) months for his possession and use of cocaine.Â  Within thirty
  (30) days of the date of this opinion, respondent shall pay the costs incurred
  by ODC and the Commission on Lawyer Conduct for the investigation and
  prosecution of this matter.Â  Further, as set forth in the Agreement, should
  respondent be reinstated to the practice of law, he shall maintain his contract
  with Lawyers Helping Lawyers and agree to drug monitoring, both for a period of
  not less than two (2) years.Â  Within fifteen days of the date of this opinion,
  respondent shall file an affidavit with the Clerk of Court showing that he has
  complied with Rule 30, RLDE, Rule 413, SCACR.
DEFINITE SUSPENSION.
TOAL, C.J., WALLER, PLEICONES, BEATTY
and KITTREDGE, JJ., concur.

respondent on interim suspension.Â  In the Matter of Drennan, (S.C. Sup. Ct. dated December 19, 2007) (Shearouse Adv. Sh. No. 43 at 55).Â

        Attorney
          General Henry D. McMaster and James G. Bogle, Jr., Senior Assistant Attorney
          General, both of Columbia, for Special Prosecutor. 
        Michael
          J. Virzi, of Columbia, for respondent.Â  
      
    
  


PER
  CURIAM:Â Â  In this attorney disciplinary
  matter, respondent and the Special Prosecutor have entered into an Agreement
  for Discipline by Consent (Agreement) pursuant to Rule 21, RLDE, Rule 413,
  SCACR.Â  In the Agreement, respondent admits misconduct and consents to the
  imposition of a definite suspension not to exceed two (2) years.Â  See Rule 7(b), RLDE, Rule 413, SCACR.Â  Respondent
  requests the suspension be made retroactive to the date of his interim
  suspension.[1]Â 
  We accept the Agreement and impose a definite suspension of two (2) years.Â 
  Because of the serious nature of respondentâ€™s misconduct, we deny respondentâ€™s
  request to make the suspension retroactive to the date of his interim
  suspension.Â  The facts, as set forth in the Agreement, are as follows.Â  
FACTS
On or about
  November 2, 2006, respondent was arrested in Richland County for the crime of
  soliciting prostitution in violation of S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 16-15-90 and Â§
  16-15-100 (2003).Â  The warrant alleged respondent met with an undercover South
  Carolina Law Enforcement Division (SLED) agent posing as a prostitute and
  solicited the undercover agent for sex.Â  
As a result of
  the same occurrences, respondent was also arrested on November 2, 2006 in Richland County for impersonating a law enforcement agent in violation of S.C. Code Ann. Â§
  16-17-720 (2003).Â  The warrant alleged that, during the encounter with the
  undercover SLED agent who was posing as a prostitute, respondent verbally
  identified himself as a SLED agent by presenting a badge and stating he was a
  SLED agent.Â  At the time of the arrests, respondent was employed on a full-time
  basis as an attorney with the Office of Disciplinary Counsel and the badge he
  presented to the undercover SLED agent was his Disciplinary Counsel badge.Â  
Respondent
  admits that, during his conversation with the undercover SLED agent, he made
  statements that she reasonably understood to be soliciting prostitution, even
  though he did not offer money but, instead, used words that reasonably
  represented an arrangement had been made by respondentâ€™s friend in the escort
  service business which would allow for sexual activity without payment.Â  Respondent
  also acknowledges that, during the encounter with the undercover SLED agent, he
  stated he had overheard information regarding investigations into prostitution
  activity while he was at SLED and stated that he might be able to provide
  information regarding future prostitution investigations.Â  Respondent admits
  that the statements concerning his ability to inform about future prostitution
  investigations were false; the Special Prosecutor has no evidence to establish
  otherwise.Â  Respondent further admits that, during the exchange with the
  undercover SLED agent, he identified himself as a â€œSLED agentâ€ and, upon her
  inquiry as to what â€œSLEDâ€ meant, he responded â€œState Law Enforcement Divisionâ€
  or words to that effect.Â  
 The
  responsibility for prosecuting respondent for these crimes was transferred to
  the Solicitorâ€™s Office of the Sixth Judicial Circuit.Â  Respondent was allowed
  to enter the Pre-Trial Intervention Program and he completed that program on or
  about September 8, 2008. 
LAW
Respondent
  admits that his misconduct constitutes grounds for discipline under Rule 413,
  RLDE, specifically Rule 7(a)(1) (lawyer shall not violate Rules of Professional
  Conduct or any other rules of this jurisdiction regarding professional conduct
  of lawyers); Rule 7(a)(5) (lawyer shall not engage in conduct tending to
  pollute the administration of justice or to bring the courts or the legal
  profession into disrepute or conduct demonstrating an unfitness to practice
  law); and Rule 7(a)(6) (lawyer shall not violate the oath of office taken upon
  admission to practice law in this State).Â  In addition, respondent admits he
  has violated the following provisions of the Rules of Professional Conduct,
  Rule 407, SCACR:Â  Rule 8.4(a) (it is
    professional misconduct for lawyer to violate the Rules of Professional
    Conduct); Rule 8.4(b) (it is professional misconduct for lawyer to commit
  a criminal act that reflects adversely on the lawyer's honesty, trustworthiness
  or fitness as a lawyer in other respects); Rule 8.4(c) (it is professional
  misconduct for lawyer to commit
  a criminal act involving moral turpitude); Rule 8.4(d) (it is professional
  misconduct for lawyer to engage in conduct involving dishonesty, fraud, deceit
  or misrepresentation); Rule 8.4(e) (it is professional misconduct for lawyer to
  engage in conduct that is prejudicial to the administration of justice); and
  Rule 8.4(f) (it is professional misconduct for lawyer to state or imply an
  ability to influence improperly a government agency or official or to achieve
  results by means that violate the Rules of Professional Conduct or other law).Â  
CONCLUSION
We accept the Agreement for Discipline by
  Consent and impose a definite suspension of two (2) years.Â  Within fifteen days
  of the date of this opinion, respondent shall file an affidavit with the Clerk
  of Court showing that he has complied with Rule 30, RLDE, Rule 413, SCACR.
DEFINITE SUSPENSION.
TOAL, C.J., WALLER, PLEICONES, BEATTY
  and KITTREDGE, JJ., concur.

[1] On November 3, 2006, respondent was placed on
  interim suspension.Â  In the Matter of Pearman, 371 S.C. 19, 637 S.E.2d 309
(2006).Â

IN THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA

          McFarland, Respondent.
      
    
  


Opinion No. 26600
Submitted December 29, 2008 - Filed February 9, 2009Â Â Â  

PUBLIC REPRIMAND


  
    
      
        Lesley M.
          Coggiola, Disciplinary Counsel, and Ericka M. Williams, Assistant Disciplinary
          Counsel, both of Columbia, for Office of Disciplinary Counsel.
        Arthur C.
          McFarland, of Charleston, pro se.
      
    
  


PER CURIAM:Â  The Office of Disciplinary Counsel
  (ODC) and respondent have entered into an Agreement for Discipline by Consent
  pursuant to Rule 21, RLDE, Rule 413, SCACR, in which respondent admits
  misconduct and agrees to either an admonition or public reprimand.Â  We accept
  the agreement and issue a public reprimand.Â  The facts, as set forth in the
  agreement, are as follows.
FACTS
Matter I
In November 2000, respondent was retained
  by Complainant A to clear title to property on Complainant Aâ€™s behalf.Â 
  Complainant A paid respondent $1,000.00 to begin the process; however, respondent
  maintains the retainer fee was actually $1,500.00.Â  
Respondent represents he met with
  Complainant A to outline the steps necessary to clear title to the property.Â 
  He further represents that he prepared a complaint.Â  In April 2003, Complainant
  A terminated respondentâ€™s service.Â  As of that date, respondent had not filed
  the complaint.
At times during the course of
  respondentâ€™s representation, respondent failed to return Complainant Aâ€™s
  telephone calls. Respondent further failed to promptly return Complainant Aâ€™s
  file as requested after the representation had been terminated.Â Â Â Â Â  
Matter II
In February 2005, Complainant B consulted
  with respondent regarding the filing of a civil case on his behalf.Â  Respondent
  agreed to review materials in Complainant Bâ€™s case to determine whether he
  would accept representation in the matter.Â  During the course of respondentâ€™s
  consultation with Complainant B, respondent received $1,000.00 from Complainant
  B to conduct some legal research.Â  Respondent decided not to proceed with the
  legal research, but failed to promptly return Complainantâ€™s $1,000.00 fee.Â  
In June 2005, Complainant B retained
  respondent to handle a motor vehicle accident claim on his behalf.Â  In July
  2005, respondent notified the insurance company he represented Complainant B.Â  
Other than a review of Complainant Bâ€™s
  medical records, respondent conducted no other meaningful work in the case.Â  In
  February 2007, Complainant B terminated respondentâ€™s representation in the motor
  vehicle accident matter and requested respondent forward the client file to his
  new lawyer.Â  Respondent failed to promptly forward Complainant Bâ€™s file as
  requested.Â  Once he did forward the file, only ten (10) days remained before expiration
  of the statute of limitations.Â  Respondent maintains it was his intention to
  file a suit prior to the expiration of the statute of limitations.Â  Respondent
  agrees he failed to keep Complainant B reasonably informed about the status of
  the motor vehicle accident case.Â  
Matter III
In January 2007, respondent was retained
  to partition property on behalf of Complainant C and two other clients.Â  On
  March 21, 2007, respondent filed suit in the action.Â  Service of the pleadings
  was not completed until August 21, 2007.Â  Respondent represents that a
  miscommunication between respondent and his legal assistant led to the delay in
  service of the pleadings.Â  
For a period of over four months,
  respondent failed to return Complainant Câ€™s telephone calls or keep Complainant
  C and the other two clients reasonably informed regarding the status of their
  case.Â  Both respondent and Complainant C represent that communications between
  them have improved.Â  
LAW
Respondent acknowledges that his
  misconduct constitutes grounds for discipline under the Rules for Lawyer
  Disciplinary Enforcement, Rule 413, SCACR, specifically Rule 7(a)(1) (it shall
  be ground for discipline for lawyer to violate Rules of Professional Conduct).Â 
  Respondent admits that by his misconduct he has violated the following Rules of
  Professional Conduct, Rule 407, SCACR:Â  Rule 1.2 (lawyer shall abide by
  clientâ€™s decision concerning objectives of representation); Rule 1.3 (lawyer
  shall act with reasonable diligence and promptness in representing client); Rule
  1.4 (lawyer shall promptly respond to reasonable requests for information);
  Rule 1.15 (lawyer shall safe keep client property); and Rule 8.4(e) (lawyer
  shall not engage in conduct prejudicial to the administration of justice).
CONCLUSION
We find that respondentâ€™s misconduct
  warrants a public reprimand.[1]Â 
  Accordingly, we accept the Agreement for Discipline by Consent and publicly
  reprimand respondent for his misconduct.
PUBLIC REPRIMAND.
TOAL, C.J., WALLER, PLEICONES, BEATTY
and KITTREDGE, JJ., concur.


[1] Respondent previously received a public
  reprimand.Â  In the Matter of McFarland, 360 S.C. 101, 600 S.E.2d 537
  (2004).Â Â  In addition, he received an admonition in 2001 and a private
  reprimand in 1996.Â  As permitted by Rule 7(b)(5), RLDE, we have considered the
  admonition and private reprimand solely upon the issue of determining the
proper sanction in the current matter.Â Â Â

  This matter is before the Court by way of a petition for a writ of certiorari to review the Court of Appeals’ decision in Wieters v. Bon-Secours-St. Francis Xavier Hosp., Inc., 378 S.C. 160, 662 S.E.2d 430 (Ct. App. 2008).  The petition for a writ of certiorari is denied because the order on appeal is not immediately appealable. We therefore vacate the Court of Appeals’ opinion.

IT  IS SO ORDERED.


  
    
     s/Jean H. Toal                                    C.J.

Columbia, South Carolina

    INTERROGATORIES TO PARTIES
(a) Availability; Procedures for Use.  Except as  limited by paragraph (b)(9), any party may serve upon any other party written  interrogatories to be answered by the party served or, if the party served is a  public or private corporation or a partnership or association or governmental  agency, by any officer or agent, who shall furnish such information as is  available to the party.  Interrogatories  may, without leave of court, be served upon the plaintiff after commencement of  the action and upon any other party with or after service of the summons and  complaint upon that party.
